email.title: Weekly Digest

image.alt: Chocolate chip biscuits and a glass of milk
image.title: Chocolate chip biscuits go very well with a glass of milk!

email.text:
Welcome to your second digest of the year!
Thank you to everyone who came to meet us at the Welcome Fair! We had a great time talking to you guys, as well as enjoying some Beat Saber and typing competitions together. We'll be announcing the winners and prizes of the typing competition in the next digest email... stay tuned for that!
Now let's dig in some important announcements for the upcoming week.
email.heading: Autumn Elections - Year Rep Nominations Open
email.text:
Nominations in the Union Autumn elections are **NOW OPEN** and close at **Midnight on Monday 14 October**!
It is an opportunity to make your voice heard within the College and the Union.
Every year students vote for an Academic Year Representative and Wellbeing Year Representative.
The Academic Year Representative receives and collates feedback from their cohort, passing this information to the Departmental Representatives or staff as appropriate. Academic Representatives have made long-lasting improvements in many areas such as the content of curricula, feedback quality and timeliness, exam timetables and formats, online learning resources, and the physical facilities available.
Wellbeing Year Representatives are part of the Wellbeing Representation Network, which aims to tackle issues such as stress and pressure, mental health, the quality of personal tutoring, how students are supported to be resilient and independent, transitioning back into study after time off, and more. Wellbeing Representatives will work with College staff, Welfare Officers, and Academic Representatives.
Year reps make **real change within the department**, with a place on regular Staff Student Committee meetings, voicing their concerns to teaching fellows and staff.
To nominate yourself and for more information on the mentioned and other roles available, visit the Union's [Autumn Elections page](https://www.imperialcollegeunion.org/your-union/autumn-elections-2019).
email.heading: CGCU Town Hall

event.text:
Interested in representing student voice in faculty decisions to how your course is ran?
As an Academic or Wellbeing Year Rep, you're on the forefront of influencing what changes to policies the Department of Computing makes during the academic year, whether that be issues with teaching staff, usage of student space, or improving department support services.
The CGCU are hosting a Town Hall to help explain the responsibilities involved, how to apply, and network with current representatives to understand how you can impact student experience, on Tuesday 8th of October from 5pm - 6pm in CAGB 200 (City & Guilds Building just next to the Main Reception). Pizza will be provided during networking, so do come along!

email.heading: Mums & Dads Lunch

event.text:
We'll be kicking off the Mums and Dads programme with an opportunity for you to meet your MaD parents and have lunch with them! We will be offering free food and drinks, as well as issuing a number of challenges. You might even win a prize!
If you're a fresher and you don't have parents assigned yet or have not registered, please let us know.
Mums and Dads parent? Be sure to turn up to this event to meet your children!

email.heading: Intro to Linux

event.text:
Are you a first year who is new to the world of computing? Then come and join us at our first academic event of the year!
Familiarity with the Linux/Unix environment and the command line is arguably one of the most important skills a software engineer today can have. Many often find it difficult at first - even if they've got quite a bit of coding experience, but DoCSoc is here to help!
We'll be covering fundamental command line skills and Linux-related knowledge that will be useful for you, as well as some more advanced tricks and looking at some different text editors. You'll also have a chance to ask any questions you may have at the end of the talk.
_This event is aimed at people who have never had any experience with Linux or the Linux terminal._

email.heading: IC Game Development Taster

event.text:
A warm welcome to everyone who is new to Imperial and welcome to the IC Game Development Society!
We will be holding our first weekly session on Tuesday 8th of October from 18:00 - 20:00 located in Huxley, room 341 run in collaboration with DoCSoc.
In this session we will try give you a flavour of game development at Imperial through a game ideation workshop followed by a gaming social at the end.
If this hasn't whetted your appetite, hopefully the free pizza will!
If you have any specific dietary requirements, please let us know a few days beforehand.

email.heading: Sponsors' Exhibition

event.text:
Come to the Great Hall on Wednesday 9th October between 2pm - 5pm to have a chance to meet all of DoCSoc's Silver and Gold sponsors this year and grab some swag.
Whether you are looking for an internship or graduate role, or simply want to know more about industry, we really recommend you come along as it's a great way to get in direct contact with recruiters and engineers from highly regarded companies and should provide invaluable insight into the recruitment process.
This event is open to all DoCSoc members (automatically includes Computing, JMC, and EIE students).

email.heading: Next Jump Workshop

event.text:
Details to come soon in an email in the coming week!
As usual, this event will be catered with lots of pizza and soft drinks. If you're a first year, don't miss out on the first sponsor event of the academic year!

email.heading: Postgraduate Drinks

event.text:
(If you are an undergraduate, i.e., BEng/MEng Computing/JMC, unfortunately this event isn't for you! Otherwise, read ahead!)
Come join us for our first ever postgraduate social and get to know each other over food and drinks, complimentary of DoCSoc. For this event, we have reserved a number of tables in Eastside Bar.
Bar tokens will be provided, eligible for both alcoholic and non-alcoholic drinks. A limited amount of canapés will be served at the start of the event.
Please note Eastside Bar (unlike our usual bar venue, Metric) has limited space, shared with other bookings, and we will not be able to accommodate all postgraduates this time round! We will be returning to Metric for future postgraduate drinks over the academic year.
This event is open to all DoCSoc postgraduates (MScs [not MEng], PhDs, postdocs, etc.).\ Membership can be purchased for £30 at docsoc.co.uk/join.

email.heading: Netcraft Introduction
email.sponsor:
Netcraft is an innovative internet services company, with offices in central Bath, Hammersmith in London and central Manchester from July 2020. Netcraft conducts internet research and provides a range of security services, including cybercrime disruption, application security testing and automated penetration testing.
Netcraft provides anti-cybercrime services for hundreds of customers around the world, including large Internet companies (e.g. Microsoft, Netflix), banks (e.g. Metro Bank, BNP Paribas, Deutsche Bank), retailers (e.g. Gumtree) and the UK Government. It also provides similar services to smaller companies at the sharp end of internet financial crime, including leading cryptocurrency exchanges and wallet providers (e.g. Coinbase), and many banks in developing countries where cybercrime is more prevalent.
Netcraft has a variety of roles available—including Graduate positions, summer placements, and industrial years—at its offices in Bath and London. We are keen to receive applications from high performing Computer Science students, although applicants must be able to demonstrate the right to work in the United Kingdom. More information on the roles and what it's like to work with Netcraft can be found in our recruitment brochure: https://www.netcraft.com/NetcraftGraduateBooklet.pdf
Come and join our talented and growing software development team! Projects involve working on a range of our anti-cybercrime services and extending our network exploration and internet security services.
We're looking for: - a broad knowledge of internet technology, including a keen interest in network security, data mining, machine learning, and web-based user interfaces; - attention to detail, and a desire to find things out empirically rather than relying on conjecture; - demonstrable programming ability and experience. - evidence of conspicuous achievement and a strong computing background, equivalent to a first-class degree in Computer Science or similar subjects; - expressive verbal and written communications skills in English. Skills in other languages are also welcomed; - a well-developed sense of precaution: someone who likes to plan for the future with suitable programming abstractions, automated test suites and version control.
Prior experience with any of the following technologies and programming languages would be helpful, but not essential: - Scripting languages like Perl, Python and PHP; - Database engines like MySQL; - Web languages like JavaScript and TypeScript, and HTML and CSS; - Automation tools like Puppet and cloud computing services like AWS; - Unix systems programming and administration, and tools like git.
To apply, email [cv@netcraft.com](mailto:cv@netcraft.com) with your CV.
email.heading: Bloomberg - Ada Lovelace Day
email.sponsor:
Join us to celebrate Ada Lovelace Day with a special women in technology themed quiz. Put your knowledge to the test, get inspired and meet our Software engineers from the Bloomberg Women in Technology & Allyship Communities. Sign up here: http://tinyurl.com/y69erchg
_More information in the PDF attached._
